reviewText:
The world is kind of a heavy place lately, and it's become hard to escape and find that moment of peace we all could really use. Everywhere we look for entertainment or relaxation reminds us of the discord and disorder seen more and more through images of violence and confrontation. Where do you turn when you want to get away from the realities of the world we're being reminded of every day?

Of course everyone enjoys the challenge and hyperactive action of first person shooters but as some of us grow older we tire of their melodramatic, heavy handed, and needlessly intense nature. Could it be possible to have that same action in a more refined, artistic, and abstract style? Lovely Planet is exactly the kind of shooter to bring us this sort of peace so needed in an entertainment industry fueled by glorified aggression.

Like a series of condensed blasts of Unreal Tournament's frantic chaos rolled up into a Katamari Damacy world of simple origami aesthetics and uplifting pop-folk melody, this is definitely a game for the open minded.

Lovely Planet has a very esoteric and eastern feel to it with it's outgoing style and upbeat pop melodies composed by multi-talented musician Calum Bowen, giving me nuances of saturday mornings as a youth watching Japanese children's programming on old VHS my Grandparents would tape and mail. While this is obviously a very personal feeling of nostalgia, there's a different form of it each player will end up discovering in their own way and tied somehow to their own past. If that reminiscent feeling isn't there for the player initially, it will be a new memory engraved into their mind in the same way our favorite things as a child stick with us.

Despite the heavy Japanese overtones from the bits of stylized text and the simplicity of it's cute and attractive design, the game was actually created by Delhi based QUICKTEQUILA and the bridging between cultures by this up-and-coming developer gives the surreal nature of it's atmosphere a touch of authenticity.

Beginning your journey into this Lovely Planet is almost overwhelming, assaulted with bright and stupefyingly cheerful audiovisuals. You're presented to an abstract world of random and seemingly unrelated trinkets and collage of colorful shapes,  sitting somewhere between the mysterious indie charm of Proteus and the otherworldly grandiose of Katamari Damacy.

Although the attractive and charming visuals may ease you into a false sense of ease and comfort, the game is no pushover. It features a very progressive learning curve that keeps you on your toes and constantly alert. The stages require finesse as you dance around a well choreographed ballet of bullets.

The first world titled simply 'City' gets you into the motions with some short and mostly linear pathways sprinkled with some adorable visual design through bright colors, odd decorations, and an onslaught of peculiar words and phrases in Japanese strewn about. Beating this first handful of levels is a lightning quick affair where each attempt will be over before you even realize it, leaving you craving the next hit of fast paced shooting and jumping action.

This pace quickly changes as you enter the second world and on as the levels begin to twist and turn into more complex patterns. Different enemies and obstacles appear forcing you to think quicker before every jump or turn of a corner, and new increasingly peculiar tasks become prevalent from protecting your distressed looking blue companions to shooting down cartoonish apples before they plummet to the ground. The obstacle-course like stages just get harder and harder, you'll begin retrying more and more, and you'll slowly become consumed in the competitive spirit of the World Records shown at the end of each stage.

Lovely Planet will cause you to wear out your restart key as you mash it mercilessly to conquer that one seemingly simple stage and in good time. You'll eventually beat these difficult and meticulously planned later levels and instantly get a feeling of satisfaction, which quickly turns into the crush of defeat as you're shown a world record only to realize you are still seconds from being the best.

Lovely Planet is a game with roots in culture, art, and the essence of what 'fun' used to stand for. It proves that art games don't need to all have the same boring or pretentious gameplay, and can be just as engaging and fun as anything else out there.

Lovely Planet is a FPS platformer in a surreal and cute world. However do not let the cuteness fool you, this game is brutally hard.

The graphics remind me of the Nintendo 64 games with crude 3D shapes mixed with occasional simple 2D textures to give character. I know this is a bit far-fetched, but I find it cute in Lovely Planet.
The gameplay is swift and responsive, the only weird part being sliding off some ledges that look like it would be possible to land on them. Framerate is perfect and the game runs well. However the FOV cannot be changed.

The idea is to get across a short level while jumping on platforms and shooting baddies. Simple enough, so there are leaderboards to compete, and stars given according to accuracy and speed. At first I kept trying to go faster and faster without understanding why my impressive runs didn't get rewarded by the game, until I learned that the third star was only given for 100% accuracy. I like a good challenge, so I worked on finishing all levels 100% with three stars.

At the start the levels were pretty straight-forward and it was fun. But then... then the apple fell too far from the tree. Literally, because falling apples is the one game mechanic that ruined the game for me. Any single apple hitting the ground triggers a game over. The early ones are thrown at the player, which is fine. However after a bit the apples are shot in the sky from a different place in the level, and just fall right where they are, whether the player is around or not.

Let me explain better how this is infuriating. You are in a part of the level, merrily shooting and platforming your way. And then, suddenly, you cross an invisible line and hear the dreaded sound of an apple been released. And now, the only thing that you can do is rush forward in the level to reach the part where the apple is located, and start shooting from afar (because the bullets take time to travel), without a target nor a crosshair, where you predict that the apple is going to fall . And then you realize that three apples were triggered, and you need to pre-shoot three different locations with pinpoint pre-accuracy and timing. So, basically, you have no choice but to quickly shoot in several directions and hope for the best, and do it again and again until you are a robot that has complete muscle memory of the right way to deal with this nonsense. And let's not talk about the moment where you have to jump on a jump-pad, and while in the air, shoot where an apple is going to land BEHIND you, then quickly turn back forward and shoot where an apple is falling in FRONT of you. I managed to do it. I did all of this. I had three stars in these levels, so 100% accuracy. But instead of being happy at my achievement, I was thinking why? why so much time wasted being a robot and not having any fun?". Then I started the 4th world

reviewText:
Lovely Planet is an enigma.

On the surface, the game is cute, bright, colorful, and has one of the best produced soundtracks I've ever heard, taking major influence from J-pop and various production styles like it. It looks adorable, it feels adorable, it is adorable.

Then you start playing it.

This game is a first person shooter that is essentially a very cute target practice sim. You need to haul it as fast as you can through various obstacles to the ending pole, shooting any and every red enemy that you see, while avoiding shooting at the blue ones. You run pretty fast, you jump very high, and you have infinite ammo in your block shooting gun. No enemies take more than one hit to kill, and only one type will shoot back at you; shooting the bullets they shoot kills them as well as stops the bullet. You have three objectives to get stars at the end of the game; beat the level (duh), beat a minimum time they give you, and have 100% accuracy on all of your shots. Sounds decently straightforward, right? That's because it is, in theory.

The first world is decently easy. However, even in this world expectations are quite high; a lot of the levels I beat the minimum time by few milliseconds, just because it's so fast paced. This might just be me being bad at the game and not being fast enough, because a lot of the world records are half the average speed. However, as angry and frustrated at both yourself and the game you get, you're never genuinely mad, because of how cute and fun the world around you is. Beat a 10 second minimum level in 9.997 seconds? That sucks, but holy sh*t this soundtrack!

The second world adds a new mechanic into the game; you need to shoot apples (tomatoes? large red bean bags?) before they hit the ground. Now, this would be very easy if your bullets had normal bullet physics; however, they move at a consist speed, about the same speed you run. So, if you need to shoot one of these things from a good distance as it's falling down, you need to aim your bullet down just above the ground so it'll collide into it. This is not as easy as it sounds, and I've had amazing runs destroyed because the apple hit the ground a few frames before the bullet hit. However, as all this difficulty stacks up and starts to become extremely frustrating, the amazing soundtrack just slowly washes it all away.

Is this game relaxing, fun, and a good takeaway from stress and other more violent and dark games? Absolutely.
Is this game frustrating, rage-inducing, and the bane of speedrunners everywhere? Absolutely.

PC Port Quality
Basic key rebinding, doesn't detect Mouse 4/5 (Thumb Buttons). Controller has no mapping, and while it has cute icons in the environment to go with it, I wouldn't at all recommend using it because of the difficulty. Graphics options are minimal (AA, Vsync, Adjustable Frame Cap incl. Unlimited). Supports multi-monitor and all common aspect ratios if not everything. No FOV Adjustment (default is okay enough for average PC user), No Crosshair even optionally. No performance issues.

Gameplay
This game is amazing, but not for the feint of heart, or for those with even average dexterity. Beyond the middle of the 3rd world, out of a total of 5, the game becomes extremely difficult, and that's even with an on-screen crosshair (built into my Asus Display), which the game completely lacks by default. Up through the 3rd world I was able to complete the 2 bonus stars for time and 100% accuracy, but beyond that point more and more levels become an immense challenge just to finish at all. In other games, if you aren't good you can beat things, but you just wont get all the points or whatever. In this, if you aren't exceptionally good, you literally will not beat the game.

More enemies, mechanics, and obstacles are added as you progress, and while most aren't portal levels of brilliant, they do a good job of mixing up how you think about different situations. Though because of the difficulty near the end, it makes it a challenge to experiment with various timings, as it puts you in situations with very little time to react and execute, though retrying from the beginning of each level is nearly instantaneous.

The controls are extremely responsive (they really need to be for the end-game), and there's more variety than you'd initially expect. Though again, you need to be good enough to even see all of it. However, once you unlock a new world, ALL of the levels are open to you instantly. You're not completely stuck if you find a level right in the middle that gives you trouble, you can come back to it later, or never at all as you only need a certain amount of stars to progress.

Presentation
The visuals are very minimal, but extremely charming in combination with the music. The game is frustrating, but the amazing music by Calum Bowen forces a smile onto your face for most of the experience. The soundtrack was free around the release of the game, and I've listened to it a considerable amount. The only thing I'd wish for, is more variety in the environments. There's definitely some there, but ones with drastically different color palettes or even nighttime levels would be a treat.

TLDR - Summary
I completely and totally recommend it for fans of shooters both old and new. It's extremely responsive and the music and visuals just make you smile. The beginning levels are a joy and they're worth experiencing for it's common sale price. Just don't plan on seeing everything unless you're already skilled in twitch shooters, or you're willing to work at it. This was clearly made by a fan of shooters and PC gaming, and other than some small adjustments, I tremendously appreciate it.

reviewText:
Having played the game up until the first level of the second world, here's what I have to say:

I have no idea what the story is,
I have no idea why I'm doing what I'm doing,
I have no idea what anything is,

but I like it.

Nothing seems apparent in the beginning, however, slowly but surely, you get a good feel for what's going on. The gameplay is solid - one part FPS, one part platforming. Both parts perform well, and while there are enemies hiding around every corner, somehow you feel like it's your fault if you die. Even though you may not see an enemy at first, you will see one of their bullets whizzing by your head, and that usually gives you enough time to react. My only gripe here is the cherry bomb - once it hits the ground, you have to restart the level, and it's a bit jarring at first because you have to experience it a couple of times to understand what happened and why.

As for level design, well... it all seems really repetetive. That's really all I have to say that's negatie, though. You play one short level after another, and there after you beat a level, it gives you your time and a 'record' time for you to beat. After enemies are introduced, it's your job to exterminate them. Miss one, and you have to start the level over. Concept is really simple. Difficulty curve is slow, if not spot on - new mechanics and enemies are gradually introduced to you so you have time to get used to what's happening.

Graphics-wise, everything is simple and polygonal, however, that just helps to boost the aesthetics. The environment is colorful and cheery, with bright pastel-like colors. The music is a nice touch as well - not fast, but still cheery and upbeat, fitting in quite nicely with the environment.

So should you get this game?

If you're into FPS games like CoD and Battlefield and such, no, this game is probably not for you - you will not be offered a high-octane competetive FPS, as that is not what this game is about.

However, if you want to relax and have some fun without the competition and fast paced gameplay, go for it. You'll have a lot of fun with this game - it's very easy to pick up and play.

TL;DR: Infuriating puzzle platformer, a less stylish 3D-version of Super Meat Boy
Don't let this game fool you with it's name and graphics -- after playing it for an hour, you'll be furious, because you won't be able to complete some level in the 2nd zone. You'll be screaming at the game, most likely sluring a lot, yet you'll get weird feeling of a satisfaction after completing the level you've been grinding for the past 15 minutes.

There's really not much to tell about it: it's basically a fast-paced puzzle platformer with weird Japanese graphics and j-pop to pair with. As of the level design, you usually have to grind as hard as you did in Super Meat Boy to complete each zone -- you have to memorize the maneuvers and timings, time your shots and watch your step carefully; hell, late levels are a lot more hardcore than Super Meat Boy, I tell you!

It's okay. Nowhere near as fun as quake live's race gamemode. It's kind of different from that, but with less depth, with the former being about movement+precision aiming (rocket jumps etc.) and this game being ONLY about precision aiming. The movement in this game is not very good. Walking down a slope will just make you instantly slide down it, way faster than you floating down from jumping.

I don't know why a game entirely about precision aiming has no crosshair. Just because the projectiles inherit momentum doesn't make a crosshair useless. All removing the crosshair does is add guesswork to the game, which is stupid when most levels have very small frame windows in which to shoot homing projectiles. The stupidity multiplies whenever said projectiles are waiting for you in front of a teleporter exit.

That being said I think most people could find enjoyment out of the first 3 worlds since their less cheesy and actually give you some freedom of how you complete the levels. The swamp (4th world) levels are filled with guess-working tiny windows of opportunity, and guessing where the falling apples(?) are going to be when your screen is entirely fog and you have no depth perception. Mountain (5th world) has even more homing missile spam in-front of you as you leave a teleporter. Not very fun or exciting, but the main point of saying all of this is that there's no freedom in how you execute these things. There's no discovery on what the most optimal route is, or how to do it.

The music is alright. The visuals are alright but they feel a bit lazy. They're not bad and their artistic talent is still there,  it just looks like the developers could do better.

reviewText:
Lovely planet is a FPS frustration/perfection game (i.e. FPS Super Meat Boy, but not nearlyl as good).

The game design is not good enough, which is a shame because it does a couple of things right and I wanted a FPS SMB.
The leveldesign is very obtuse on a sizeable chunk of the levels and the game uses showing you the path via camera animations as a crutch. (Like Prince of Persia Sands of Time did, and it wasn't good back then)
The first few levels are quite easy until you get the enemies with the homing missiles, then it gets frustrating.
The missiles have a very narrow turnradius so that you can't dodge them (which would've been fun, think of N or SMB), you have to shoot them before they reach you, there is no crosshair and aiming your shots is unintuitive (I guess they retain some of your momentum; they definitely do not behave like rockets,  thtough it's not as intuitive to aim as Tribes Ascend).
Those enemies look exactly like previous enemies with completely different behaviour, except that they have a hat on. Same color, same shape and even the projectiles look the same!
When you fall down a ledge, there is no physics, instead of falling with the same gravity as you would had you  jumped, you get instantly teleported to the lower ground which is very jarring and can make you run into (non-homing) projectiles that you didn't even see.
If your gun clips into enemies, you can't kill them until you back out again.
The leaderboards are full of cheaters with impossible times and unlike Dustforce, there are no replays; this leaves you with just finishing the levels like that or trying to get 3 stars by beating a preset time (which is sometimes hard but doable) and finishing the level with 100% accuracy which is both a matter of memorization and patience.

The music is upbeat, which lessens the frustration.

It's not the worst but it's sub-par.

What is lovely planet?Lovely planet is a twitch first person shooter rage game platformer thing. In the game you traverse through different colourful levels, trying to kill alll enemies, not miss any shots and beat your time. It may sound easy but believe me when I say it's not... there will be many obstacles alog the way.

The love and the hateIf you rage easily in games dont get this, okay? Most of the time you will be repeating the same stage time after time again because you made stupid mistakes. The other portion of the time you will be smashing your keyboard and screaming words that you didnt even know you could say. But: Im not saying thats a bad thing because its not. It adds to playtime and it make winning a level feel very rewarding.

The two most amazing aspects of this game for me are the artstyle and soundtrack. It really makes me chuckle when I realise Iv been screaming at a bunch of colourful polygons and a happy japenese tune. They both remind me alot of Japan and I think thats what they were going for considering the random japenese writing everywhere. The artstyle consists of minimilistic colourful blobs that make it easy to tell enemies and ground apart with their colours that stand out. The music in itself makes the game. The music is a nice upbeat happy track which makes you forget about all your troubles and just stand and listen. It is so happy I wonder how it could be played over the top of such an evil game! In fact I am listening to it while reading this review and it makes me not want to list a bad point about the game!

The gameplay in this game is the usual. Considering that it is mainly concentrated on platforming and twitch shooting which I hate it still felt smooth and I felt as if my shots were hitting when they should. The gun felt nice although you couldnt change what gun you had which I thought would of been cool although it probably would of messed up the leaderboards for speedrunners. So I think this game could use a bit more variety to make it a bit more intresting and unique.

Something this game is missing is a story which although twitch shooters dont normally have a story I think that super meat boy pulled of a pretty nice story so this could probably do it to! Also I think a story would of made me want to progress a bit further into the game whereas right now Iv given up because Iv been stuck for an hour. Also It might add to the replayability.

reviewText:
Wanted to like this game, and started to, but then when I finally realized the idea behind the game and and mechanics reinforced by the design I ultimately have to say no. I'll start by saying I love the idea of the opposite setting to the gameplay; hard precision fps in a cartoon world. The characters are cute, the music is nice. I have no problem you only use a bow and shoot the game people, and the levels are pretty similar. At first I loved the game, as I found it tough but mostly fair. Most parts just took a little practice. Around world 3 and especially 4, the game really started to go in the wrong direction. I have been playing FPS games all my life and have gotten very good and have played tons of different types of ones, so I can comment pretty confidently on this.

My first problem is the aiming. There are no crosshairs, which I would be fine with, but the shooting and aiming is off. Instead of your shots going in front of you where they should, they go off to the side and are unpredictable. You have to turn your body to shoot in front of you. They should either have included crosshairs showing where off to the side you shoot, or just had you shoot in front of you without crosshairs. I died so many times from something coming at me in the center of my screen or something I wanted to shoot, only the have the bullets go to the side, or below, or anywhere but where they should have gone. In a shooter requiring precision and timing, this is a no-no.

There were problems with enemies. First off, there are homing shots. Now normally with a homing shot if you dodge it is misses you, and with a bullet or something it would keep going and hit into something. In this game thats not true somehow. If you dodge a homing shot, you instant die. Which means if you miss the tiny little moving thing (with the poor aiming) coming at you, you auto die and restart the level. My dodges should count, but the same makes a mistake here. Next up are the apples in the air you have to shoot. I have no problem with shooting things out of the air, but the game starts to overuse it. Instead of it at certain parts and in certain levels, the game starts having them throughout the level, and EVERY single level. They usually also use 2 at a time, and pair that with homing missiles. It just becomes annoying. This changes the gameplay. Instead of me having to make precision shots and sometimes shoot things out of the air, but also have little breaks and go at my own pace at times in between things and make levels more fair, you basically just have to keep moving forward at all times and you need to follow the developers set pace. This makes me not feel like I'm moving through the level, but I am only a roller coaster the developers made, and my only input is turning and shooting. It also makes it so even if you dodge and shoot things, if you don't keep pace or see where the apple is, you die and start over. Where before you got to enjoy yourself with the challenge, and time was for the leaderboards and tryhards, now it becomes the only thing that matters.

The game finally comes to a head in the 4th world, where (dumbest design decision I could think of) the entire world is surrounded in fog, and you can't see ahead of you. This turns every level into you jumping not knowing what is next and where you are going. You see a ball at the last second or the homing missiles right when they are on you, taking away aiming and making it reflexes or luck. The other problem is this forces this game into the worst offense. Instead of it being skill, it becomes repetition. Because you can't see where you are going next, and every next part has a new homing missing you have to hit first try and you die, or 2 apples falling that you can't see but have to keep running forward and start shooting hopefully to hit, you have to find out from error. Every level becomes the same. You start one part, fail, repeat, figure that part out, jump into the next area without seeing whats next, keep running because you hear falling object, get there too late, start over, keep redoing all of that till you sprayed enough to kill the object, get to next part, die because you can't see whats next, die, repeat ALL of it over again, and keep doing that till you finally beat that 1 level. It becomes less based on your skill or ability to think on the fly, but slowly figuring out where each little thing is, and spending 100 tries on one level before you finally beat it. That's not good game design. I can make a boss with 150 hitpoints and you do 1 damage a hit, and you have 1 hit death and you have to start all over. People will spend hours repeating the fight till they beat him, and only a few will, but just because something requires 100 times doesn't make it well made, some people just like it because the few that want to waste their lives to try and beat it feel good about themselves after they finally do. Some of us have better things in life to do. If the game design in these later levels was well made, it would just take skill, and those of us with good aiming and everything would be able to beat it quickly and relatively easily. But spending dozens and hundreds of retries memorizing patterns and every single little thing to finally beat 1 level, isn't worth it or a sign of skilled design. And since there are no checkpoints or amount of life, and 1 hit means you have to redo everything, even if you beat a really hard part or a few in a row, and a new part you havent seen yet punishes you for doing it for the first time, you lose all of your progress, which is annoying. Also since a lot of parts require spraying and some luck, you may not be able to beat the part you did before again for a bit. Multiple parts I had to shoot an apple in the fog I couldn't see before it fell, so I had to start shooting based on memory of where it was from my last playthrough, and I wouldn't know I had been missing it until it was too late, now thats poor game design. And mix all the problems of homing, poor aiming, tons of timed apples, and the grinding memorizing gameplay, and fog, and you made me realize this isn't a game about skill or fun, its about repetition and tiny little progress after tons of repeated efforts. I'd rather find something that rewards talent more than time spent. If only the game stuck with the ideas of the first 2-3 worlds.  5.5/10.

reviewText:
Alright- I'll be the devil's advocate here. Lovely Planet is a Quake-esque first person platformer and bullet hell shooter. People are comparing this game to Super Meat Boy, but I disagree completely. Not only that, but I think this game is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. Here are my points:

Super Meat Boy is about precision, and tight controls. Meat Boy himself is basically a walking hitbox- he's a tiny cube that dies if he touches any enemy or any environmental obstacle, and while that insta-death aspect is true in this game, really nothing else is even close to similar to Meat Boy.

Unline Meat Boy, LP is in first-person, which is a challenge for bullet hell-style insta-death games, because traditionally the idea of a bullet hell is that you can see what's going to hit you and be able to dodge it based on your hitbox, whether it be that glwing dot on the back of your spaceship or Meat Boy's tiny, but rigidly defined body. In an FPS, however, you lose that precision. When a bullet is flying toward you, you have no clue how far you need to dodge to actually have it not hit you, which makes a lot of deaths in this game a result of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• design rather than lack of skill. First-person view also restricts your vision- in a 2D shooter or platformer, you have all the information right in front of you, but in an FPS, you have to be constantly swiveling around, trying to see everything around you, and that restriction of your vision can be frustrating.

The same goes for the platforming- very few FPS games ever do precision platforming because it's just so ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• to pull off: in a game where you can't see your own legs and can't see your own hitbox, jumping into obstacles and getting a death can often be the result of hazy game design rather than being bad at the game, and people don't like that. People want to die because they're ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• players, not because not enough thought went into the design of the game.

Yet again, the shooting suffers from similar falling-off points: lack of clarity being the main one. I find it hard to even call this game precision" when it doesn't even have a crosshair

reviewText:
Alright, so I would give this game an 8/10 at most, but there are still a lot of things wrong with it.

Let's start off with what the game is.

Lovely planet is basically an first-person shooter where you are trying to get to the end of the level as fast as you can while shooting all the enemies, and avoiding any other obstacles. The game starts off easy, and dying is quite forgiving. Every level has a maximum yield of three stars; One for beating the level, another for beating it within a time limit, and one for having 100% accuracy.

As the game progresses, you will most likely find yourself redoing levels over and over and over because you missed a shot, or you weren't quick enough causing you to not get all three stars. There are basic mechanics in the beginning, and as the game progresses, there are much more complex ones. It really tries to teach you how to play the game during the whole game without too much obvious tips.

Now for the bad of the game.

Sadly, the game doesn't feel as if it is made with all the effort the developer could have put into it. The first thing you will find is that the game doesnt have settings to change mouse sensitivity, or even a way to rebind keys. There is also no cross hair for your gun, which can be frustrating considering you are striving for that 100% accuracy. There isn't much else to do after the game is done, making this game pretty straightforward to complete.

If you are looking for a game to just try and complete without any worry of how many lives you have, or if you just want to try and challenge yourself by completing every level, this is a good game for you. It has a ton of secrets in it, and the achievements work just fine. If you don't like games that can be frustrating, or games that have no storyline whatsoever, then I would recommend looking for another game. This game has a casual feel to it, but it feels a lot like a bullet hell type of casual fps.

With friendly environments, pleasant music, and bad guys that look like they just need a hug, Lovely Planet isn‚Äôt your usual FPS. Lovely Planet leans more on the challenge and precision of a 100% speedrun attempt side of things. If you‚Äôre going through the game just to play it, it can still be as frustrating as trying for the perfect run.

Lovely Planet is nice enough to give you unlimited ammo and infinite lives. Let‚Äôs say you want to go for a perfect 3-star run. First off, you need to get it done fast. While you‚Äôre getting it done fast, you‚Äôll also need to work on your shooting. While you have all of the ammo in the world at your disposal, you are dinged for poor aim. You‚Äôll need to work on the motto of a sniper with the ‚Äúone shot, one kill‚Äù thought process. You may want to work on your platforming skills as well since there is a lot of jumping in Lovely Planet too.

If you‚Äôre just looking to do a simple romp though the game, you‚Äôre still up for a challenge. The game starts to place bad guys around corners or put a few of them with itchy trigger fingers all looking and waiting for you to come out of a door. The jumps can be a little difficult as well since the jumping is almost so precise that it feels a little too strong. It takes some getting used to because most games have been focusing on realism and all of a sudden Lovely Planet says, ‚Äújumping should be more fun!‚Äù

The combination of first-person shooter and precision platformer is tricky to pull off, but with the exception of one major design flaw, Lovely Planet does it pretty well.

The first aspect of this game that stuck out to me was the minimal, pastel-color visual design. Combined with the aggressively cheery (and quite good) J-pop soundtrack, it helps mitigate that the game is (at points) ridiculously difficult--I know I would probably have lost my patience with a game of this style that insisted on being grim and gritty. But, beyond that, this kind of game just flows better with minimal environments. By stripping away most potential distractions, the path and objectives (shoot all the red things, don't shoot the blue things, get to the lavender thing) become very clear.

This is important, because Lovely Planet is a game that encourages you to move very quickly: if you stop moving, you will probably die. This can lead to a pretty rocky start, but as you get the hang of the game, you get better and better at whizzing through levels, bouncing around with your impossible levels of FPS air control and felling enemies with single shots. As such, the game's biggest strength is that its level design facilitates this kind of gameplay. The levels are quite hard, but they are constructed so that finding the right path through them is fun rather than a grind.

One criticism I have seen leveled at the game is that the gameplay can get somewhat monotonous, but I think this is more due to the visual design than the individual levels. The environments don't change very much between worlds, which, although preserving the nicely minimal atmosphere, gets dull. Also, some of the later enemies' abilities aren't very well explained, and given that everything instantly kills, it can be kind of hard to tell what an enemy is doing the first few times it gets you. However, this doesn't weigh too much on the game compared to the one big problem:

A lot of the challenge comes from tests of accurate shooting, rather than tricky platforming jumps or constant reflex tests. This is quite a sensible approach, but it would be significantly more fun if the gun had a crosshair. As it is, it doesn't, and given that the second and third worlds are largely based around skeet-shooting of a sort (enemies that kill you if they hit the ground) and enemies with homing projectiles that you have to shoot out of the air, respectively, this adds an unnecessarily irritating learning curve to aiming.

The combination of first-person shooter and precision platformer is tricky to pull off, but with the exception of one major design flaw, Lovely Planet does it pretty well.

The first aspect of this game that stuck out to me was the minimal, pastel-color visual design. Combined with the aggressively cheery (and quite good) J-pop soundtrack, it helps mitigate that the game is (at points) ridiculously difficult--I know I would probably have lost my patience with a game of this style that insisted on being grim and gritty. But, beyond that, this kind of game just flows better with minimal environments. By stripping away most potential distractions, the path and objectives (shoot all the red things, don't shoot the blue things, get to the lavender thing) become very clear.

This is important, because Lovely Planet is a game that encourages you to move very quickly: if you stop moving, you will probably die. This can lead to a pretty rocky start, but as you get the hang of the game, you get better and better at whizzing through levels, bouncing around with your impossible levels of FPS air control and felling enemies with single shots. As such, the game's biggest strength is that its level design facilitates this kind of gameplay. The levels are quite hard, but they are constructed so that finding the right path through them is fun rather than a grind.

One criticism I have seen leveled at the game is that the gameplay can get somewhat monotonous, but I think this is more due to the visual design than the individual levels. The environments don't change very much between worlds, which, although preserving the nicely minimal atmosphere, gets dull. Also, some of the later enemies' abilities aren't very well explained, and given that everything instantly kills, it can be kind of hard to tell what an enemy is doing the first few times it gets you. However, this doesn't weigh too much on the game compared to the one big problem:

A lot of the challenge comes from tests of accurate shooting, rather than tricky platforming jumps or constant reflex tests. This is quite a sensible approach, but it would be significantly more fun if the gun had a crosshair. As it is, it doesn't, and given that the second and third worlds are largely based around skeet-shooting of a sort (enemies that kill you if they hit the ground) and enemies with homing projectiles that you have to shoot out of the air, respectively, this adds an unnecessarily irritating learning curve to aiming.

Still, none of this overrules the fact that the first time I started to write this review, I thought, Wait

The goal of each level is to shoot all the enemies (and certain objects) that are strategically placed throughout the course all in one go.  There are no checkpoints.  If you die, you start the level over.  Completing the level with proficient time and gun accuracy awards you with an extra star.  The game's difficulty increases at a moderate pace and each level offers a unique challenge.  New game mechanics are thrown in at certain points along with new enemies.  You may get stuck on a level now and then but you don't feel hopeless.  You learn from each failure and feel like you are improving as a player.  The gameplay is complimented by the visuals which manage to be quirky and charming all while being extremely simple.  The music fits right along with the art style with an upbeat tempo that puts you in a good mood.

Most AAA titles these days have not given me the amount of enjoyment I've gotten from this game.  And those games cost roughly 5 to 10 times more than this one!  I honestly would have spent 20 dollars for this game. It's a steal for the price.

I can't say I've actually finished the game, but at this point I have to say I'm done with it. And that's only after a grand total of maybe 70 minutes of playing it. Don't let the cute aesthetic with its simple pastel colored shapes and cutesy cheerful anime music deceive you, this thing right here is about as hardcore FPS as it gets. Why? First person precision jumping levels while wielding a gun without a crosshair, that's why. You have to hit every single enemy or you can't win the level. You have to dodge every projectile because everything is a one-hit-kill. You have to shoot out apples from the sky after they're being launched from a catapult before they touch the ground, otherwise you lose the level. And for some enemies you actually have to shoot their projectiles themselves since they home in on you, before you can engage the enemies themselves. The game is hard, and I do mean hard because everything is on the clock, events constantly trigger while you're just moving forward and if you're not 100% concentrated on the game you can forget getting anywhere here.

The game does give you some help though, at the start of any level you can preview the upcoming challenges to prepare yourself for what's to come, which is a nice feature, especially when the game at the end of a level tells you you missed an enemy and you have no ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• clue where he was hiding.

For all the praise I can give it for being an undiluted FPS experience that truly tests your skills as a player, there are a couple of criticisms I want to lodge at it. First and foremost, it seems like a very short game overall. They claim that there are a hundred levels in the game but after 70 minutes, my arthritic old ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• that's not used to twitch shooters anymore managed to get through 75% of the levels. And that's with excessive trial and error since most levels can be beaten in a couple of seconds. So I simply have to assume that by the end of it, a more skilled player will beat the game in under say 2 hours. It doesn't cost much so I guess the price is justified, but in the end, the whole experience is just running through levels as fast as possible while taking out all the enemies and never getting hit. There's literally no story here, just obstacle course after obstacle course and it's clearly geared towards speedrunners because the game keeps time of your performance and then insults you by showing you all the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s who managed to beat the game 5 times faster than you did. I can appreciate the game for what it is and the execution is basically perfect, but to me this isn't a game that I'll be remembering all that much because there's really no substance there. I'm the kind of gamer that likes a game to tell me a story, not just present me with some mechanics, well thought out they though may be.

They're not asking for much cash here so I guess even though I'm not overly pleased with the game, I'll give it a recommendation for people who really want a challenging, unforgiving shooter that just might catch you off guard because of the unconventional aesthetic. Though if you want to have it a bit cheaper, there's currently a Humble Bundle offer that's definitely worth picking up so you can get it a bit cheaper.

Lovely Planet is essentially a merciless speedrunner with Japanese undertones (although it should be noted that the Developer QuickTequila is located and based in New Delhi as stated in their twitter) and a cute art style, and a nice upbeat kind of music score (created by Calum Bowen whose soundcloud and bandcamp you should check out if you enjoy the game's music). The game boils down to shooting anything that is red and/or has an angry face while navagating through a labyrinth like map that can range from easy to hard all while being timed as you compete against a leaderboard of other players who have beat the game in a certain amount of time. What makes the game difficult, enjoyable, and challenging is that the gun does not have cross hairs and that the movement of your character is enhanced (in the sense that you move fast, you jump far, and you just have an overall snappy and springy movement). The time aspect makes the game addicting as you constantly try to compete with others (the closest I've gotten is roughly 5.45 seconds to complete a map where the #10 rank for that map was 5.25 and goes down to almost 2.20 seconds for rank #1).

This has been repeated quite a few times in the reviews I've read below, but I would like to repeat them once more as they are a very accurate description of the game. Lovely Planet takes the speedrunning aspects of Supermeatboy, the springy mechanics of the Super Sam series, and the aesthetics of Katmary Damacy to create an enjoyable game for the price that is offered of $5.99. I myself bought the game in a recent humblebundle for roughly $5 with other games, but would recommend it to anyone who finds themself debating if $5.99 (or the regional equivalent) is worth the investment. If you are someone who enjoys speed running and some nostalgia from old Japanese-esque aesthetic PS2 games then Lovely Planet is worth the price.

I don't normally write reviews, but after finishing this wonderful game, I can't help but try to convince others to give it a try. To start, Lovely Planet is a game about shooting angry red guys. In order to get all 3 stars for a level, you must kill every enemy, beat the level fast enough, and not miss a single shot. With the low shot speed of your bullets, this last one can be a pain, but all of the game's enemies are stationary (except for apples, which can hardly be considered enemies) and you'll get used to the gun.

The game has great visuals and music, especially if you enjoyed the katamari series. Even after hearing the same song for a few hours, you shouldn't get sick of it unless you really hate jpop.

For me, the game really shines in its wonderful level design and difficulty curve. The first world is quite easy and will introduce you to the mechanics without being too punishing. As the game progresses, however, you'll find that every new level is just slightly outside of your skill level - not easy but never impossible. As someone who never plays first person shooters, I never felt that a level was too difficult to complete with all 3 stars. As far as the level design, there were multiple occasions where I saw what the level wanted me to do and got giddy with excitement, completely in love with the elegance of the design.

I can't recommend this game enough. This is a game that I will always remember fondly, and I'll probably play it again in a few years when I've forgotten the specifics of the levels.

I didn't exactly know what to expect when I first played this game, and initially it looked like an interesting time-killer when I was bored and needed to play something different. On the surface, this game begins as a fun, cute platforming FPS in which you have to reach the finish pole while also eliminating every enemy in the level, these enemies being red blobs of various shapes. Some of these enemies shoot bullets which you can parry by shooting with your own gun. Wanting to get all the achievements, I had to get 3 stars on every level, one for finishing, one for finishing quickly, and one for 100% accuracy. This was an enjoyable challenge because it kept things tense in the first few worlds as I had to aim my shots carefully and be hasty.

The last 2 worlds, Swamp and Mountains, were a whole different story however. Homing bullets were introduced, ones that you must shoot or death is basically guaranteed. Levels became misty, and homing bullets started flying out of nowhere. Bombs that are launched and must be shot before they hit the ground or you are killed instantly involve having to gauge where the bomb will be at a certain time and shooting at that spot, which is more fun than it sounds. With all these elements combined, eventually, the game turned into one of the hardest FPS/platforming experiences I've had, at least in order to get 3 stars in every level. Due to a requirement of 100% accuracy, every shot had to count, and no excess shots were allowed. After hours of memorising and practice, I would have to progress through the level, flicking and swiping to the next target, doing 90 and 180 turns constantly in order to shoot the various obstacles in my way. Despite all this difficulty, when you finally reach that finish pole with 100% accuracy, it feels makes you feel like some action movie star or an aim-botter of some kind :P. While torturing and rage-inducing, the experience of succeeding in this way is unmatched, and the main reason why I recommend this game, and what makes it so enjoyable.

There are also a number of secrets in the game, which are fun to look for and find, especially the fabled Planet Shrine" secret which is an elusive one and may require some research to be discovered.

I didn't exactly know what to expect when I first played this game, and initially it looked like an interesting time-killer when I was bored and needed to play something different. On the surface, this game begins as a fun, cute platforming FPS in which you have to reach the finish pole while also eliminating every enemy in the level, these enemies being red blobs of various shapes. Some of these enemies shoot bullets which you can parry by shooting with your own gun. Wanting to get all the achievements, I had to get 3 stars on every level, one for finishing, one for finishing quickly, and one for 100% accuracy. This was an enjoyable challenge because it kept things tense in the first few worlds as I had to aim my shots carefully and be hasty.

The last 2 worlds, Swamp and Mountains, were a whole different story however. Homing bullets were introduced, ones that you must shoot or death is basically guaranteed. Levels became misty, and homing bullets started flying out of nowhere. Bombs that are launched and must be shot before they hit the ground or you are killed instantly involve having to gauge where the bomb will be at a certain time and shooting at that spot, which is more fun than it sounds. With all these elements combined, eventually, the game turned into one of the hardest FPS/platforming experiences I've had, at least in order to get 3 stars in every level. Due to a requirement of 100% accuracy, every shot had to count, and no excess shots were allowed. After hours of memorising and practice, I would have to progress through the level, flicking and swiping to the next target, doing 90 and 180 turns constantly in order to shoot the various obstacles in my way. Despite all this difficulty, when you finally reach that finish pole with 100% accuracy, it feels makes you feel like some action movie star or an aim-botter of some kind :P. While torturing and rage-inducing, the experience of succeeding in this way is unmatched, and the main reason why I recommend this game, and what makes it so enjoyable.

There are also a number of secrets in the game, which are fun to look for and find, especially the fabled Planet Shrine" secret which is an elusive one and may require some research to be discovered.
